channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: South Korea's parliament votes to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol
item.description: South Korea's parliament impeached Presisdent Yoon Suk Yeol for his attempt to impose martial, the first time such a measure had been imposed on the nation in more than four decades.
item.content:encoded:
South Korea's parliament impeached Presisdent Yoon Suk Yeol for his attempt to impose martial, the first time such a measure had been imposed on the nation in more than four decades.

(Image credit: Anthony Wallace)
item.dc:creator: Anthony Kuhn

item.title: Will The FDA finally ban Red No. 3? A decision could come soon
item.description: The food colorant has been linked to behavioral problems in children, including inattention and hyperactivity. California passed a law to ban it last year.
item.content:encoded:
The food colorant has been linked to behavioral problems in children, including inattention and hyperactivity. California passed a law to ban it last year.

(Image credit: mtreasure)
item.dc:creator: Allison Aubrey

item.title: 80 years later, Glenn Miller's sudden disappearance remains unsolved
item.description: Glenn Miller was the swing era's biggest star. Then, he vanished without a trace.
item.content:encoded:
Glenn Miller was the swing era's biggest star. Then, he vanished without a trace.

(Image credit: D. Hess/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Julian Ring

item.title: South Korea's parliament votes to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol over his martial law order
item.description: South Korea's parliament voted Saturday to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol as authorities investigate allegations of rebellion over his controversial Dec. 3 martial law decree.
item.content:encoded:
South Korea's parliament voted Saturday to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol as authorities investigate allegations of rebellion over his controversial Dec. 3 martial law decree.

(Image credit: Kiim Do-hoon)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Supreme Court to consider whether Catholic group is exempt from religious taxes
item.description: At issue is whether the charity Catholic Charities is qualified to be exempt from state unemployment taxes as a religious institution.
item.content:encoded:
At issue is whether the charity Catholic Charities is qualified to be exempt from state unemployment taxes as a religious institution.

(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: American citizen Travis Timmerman is now with U.S. forces after being found in Syria
item.description: Travis Timmerman, a U.S. citizen found wandering barefoot in Damascus after being freed from a Syrian prison following the fall of the Assad regime, was handed over to U.S. forces in Syria on Friday.
item.content:encoded:
Travis Timmerman, a U.S. citizen found wandering barefoot in Damascus after being freed from a Syrian prison following the fall of the Assad regime, was handed over to U.S. forces in Syria on Friday.

(Image credit: Manu Brabo for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf

item.title: Paula Abdul settles suit alleging sexual assault by 'Idol' producer Nigel Lythgoe
item.description: Paula Abdul and former American Idol producer Nigel Lythgoe have agreed to settle a lawsuit in which she alleged he sexually assaulted her in the early 2000s when she was a judge on the show.
item.content:encoded:
Paula Abdul and former American Idol producer Nigel Lythgoe have agreed to settle a lawsuit in which she alleged he sexually assaulted her in the early 2000s when she was a judge on the show.

(Image credit: Chris Pizzello)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: People in Syria Lost and Found
item.description:
The U.N. estimates over a 100,00 people have gone missing in Syria under the regime of Bashar al-Assad. And many families never knew the fate of their loved ones. Now that the regime has fallen, the search is on for the missing. We join some Syrians on that search.

Sign up for State of the World+ to listen sponsor-free and support the work of NPR journalists. Visit plus.npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
The U.N. estimates over a 100,00 people have gone missing in Syria under the regime of Bashar al-Assad. And many families never knew the fate of their loved ones. Now that the regime has fallen, the search is on for the missing. We join some Syrians on that search.

Sign up for State of the World+ to listen sponsor-free and support the work of NPR journalists. Visit plus.npr.org.
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: Texas challenges shield laws by suing New York doctor who prescribed abortion pills
item.description: Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton filed the lawsuit against a New York doctor who prescribed abortion pills for a client near Dallas, pitting an abortion ban against laws that protect physicians.
item.content:encoded:
Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton filed the lawsuit against a New York doctor who prescribed abortion pills for a client near Dallas, pitting an abortion ban against laws that protect physicians.

(Image credit: David Erickson)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Can Syria avoid another slide into autocracy?
item.description:
The brutal regime of Bashar al Assad fell over the weekend with dizzying speed. Syrians within the country and around the world burst into celebration.

Now, the rebel group Hay'at Tahrir al Sham, or HTS has to govern. They are designated a terrorist organization by the US.

And some worry that HTS could slide into its own kind of autocratic regime.

That fear is not unfounded. Across the Middle East and North Africa, many revolutions have overthrown autocrats, only for those countries to descend back into chaos or a more oppressive rule.

The Syrian revolution began amid a wave of uprisings in the region that led to new, undemocratic regimes. Can Syria avoid a similar fate today?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
The brutal regime of Bashar al Assad fell over the weekend with dizzying speed. Syrians within the country and around the world burst into celebration.

Now, the rebel group Hay'at Tahrir al Sham, or HTS has to govern. They are designated a terrorist organization by the US.

And some worry that HTS could slide into its own kind of autocratic regime.

That fear is not unfounded. Across the Middle East and North Africa, many revolutions have overthrown autocrats, only for those countries to descend back into chaos or a more oppressive rule.

The Syrian revolution began amid a wave of uprisings in the region that led to new, undemocratic regimes. Can Syria avoid a similar fate today?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

(Image credit: Getty Images)
